20101231194055.000|20101231194057.000|TR0|for Alzheimer's disease.  Did you know -- 
20101231194057.000|20101231194100.000|TR0|did you know that the only way to diagnose

20101231194109.000|20101231194111.000|TR0| For people that don't want to do all 
20101231194111.000|20101231194114.000|TR0|this, they can do scarless surgery.  It's

20101231194116.000|20101231194119.000|TR0|and it's expected within the next year.
20101231194119.000|20101231194121.000|TR0|
20101231194121.000|20101231194123.000|TR0|And the best way to treat cancer is catch 
20101231194123.000|20101231194126.000|TR0|it early.  I've heard about telomeres  
20101231194126.000|20101231194128.000|TR0|(ph).  I know cancer has telomeres in it, 
20101231194128.000|20101231194130.000|TR0|but there's going to be a new blood test 
20101231194130.000|20101231194133.000|TR0|for something new and here to tell us 
20101231194133.000|20101231194135.000|TR0|about it is Melissa Lechner from the 
20101231194135.000|20101231194137.000|TR0|University of Southern California, Keck 
20101231194137.000|20101231194140.000|TR0|School of Medicine.       Tell me about 
20101231194140.000|20101231194142.000|TR0|this.  I'm so excited that we're going to 
20101231194142.000|20101231194144.000|TR0|be able to, what, take a finger prick and 
20101231194144.000|20101231194147.000|TR0|tell us the chances are that we have 
20101231194147.000|20101231194149.000|TR0|cancer.  Tell me about it.
20101231194149.000|20101231194151.000|TR0|
20101231194151.000|20101231194154.000|TR0|MELISSA LECHNER, KECK SCHOOL OF MEDICINE, 
20101231194154.000|20101231194156.000|TR0|USC:  Thank you for having us.
20101231194156.000|20101231194158.000|TR0|
20101231194158.000|20101231194201.000|TR0|At the University of Southern California, 
20101231194201.000|20101231194203.000|TR0|we're developing a new cancer test that 
20101231194203.000|20101231194205.000|TR0|uses your own body's host defense system 
20101231194205.000|20101231194208.000|TR0|to let us detect cancer earlier.  We're 
20101231194208.000|20101231194210.000|TR0|very excited.  It's really going to change 
20101231194210.000|20101231194212.000|TR0|the way we diagnose, manage and treat 
20101231194212.000|20101231194215.000|TR0|cancer in the future.
20101231194215.000|20101231194217.000|TR0|
20101231194217.000|20101231194219.000|TR0|MYERS:  Do we need this universal -- is 
20101231194219.000|20101231194222.000|TR0|this good?  Will it check for breast 
20101231194222.000|20101231194224.000|TR0|cancer and lung cancer and all those 
20101231194224.000|20101231194227.000|TR0|things?
20101231194227.000|20101231194229.000|TR0|
20101231194229.000|20101231194231.000|TR0|LECHNER:  Right.  So right now we think of 
20101231194231.000|20101231194234.000|TR0|cancer as a disease that has lung cancer, 
20101231194234.000|20101231194236.000|TR0|breast cancer, melanoma, and looking at it 
20101231194236.000|20101231194238.000|TR0|as a disparate set of diseases requires a 
20101231194238.000|20101231194241.000|TR0|different test, different therapy for 
20101231194241.000|20101231194243.000|TR0|every type of cancer and we don't have 
20101231194243.000|20101231194245.000|TR0|those right now.
20101231194245.000|20101231194248.000|TR0|
20101231194248.000|20101231194250.000|TR0|By looking at it as the way the immune 
20101231194250.000|20101231194252.000|TR0|system interacts with it, then we can 
20101231194252.000|20101231194255.000|TR0|think of cancer as one disease, which 
20101231194255.000|20101231194257.000|TR0|makes it much easier to diagnose and to 
20101231194257.000|20101231194259.000|TR0|treat.
20101231194259.000|20101231194302.000|TR0|
20101231194302.000|20101231194304.000|TR0|And we've discovered a set of biomarkers 
20101231194304.000|20101231194306.000|TR0|that lets us look at how our body's 
20101231194306.000|20101231194309.000|TR0|defenses interact with the defenses.  And 
20101231194309.000|20101231194311.000|TR0|so, we're able then to make one test, one 
20101231194311.000|20101231194313.000|TR0|universal test that should really help 
20101231194313.000|20101231194316.000|TR0|reduce costs, make it a simple way -- it 
20101231194316.000|20101231194318.000|TR0|can be done at any hospital.
20101231194318.000|20101231194320.000|TR0|
20101231194320.000|20101231194323.000|TR0|MYERS:  What are you testing for?  Is this 
20101231194323.000|20101231194325.000|TR0|like a byproduct of the cancer itself or 
20101231194325.000|20101231194328.000|TR0|what?
20101231194328.000|20101231194330.000|TR0|
20101231194330.000|20101231194332.000|TR0|LECHNER:  It's actually a population of 
20101231194332.000|20101231194335.000|TR0|immune cells that's in your body.  It 
20101231194335.000|20101231194337.000|TR0|arises in the setting of cancer, it's not 
20101231194337.000|20101231194339.000|TR0|found in healthy individuals.  And a 
20101231194339.000|20101231194342.000|TR0|number of these cells increase.  The more 
20101231194342.000|20101231194344.000|TR0|cancer has spread, the bigger your cancer 
20101231194344.000|20101231194346.000|TR0|is.  And then conversely, if treatment is 
20101231194346.000|20101231194349.000|TR0|successful or you're in remission, then 
20101231194349.000|20101231194351.000|TR0|the number of these cells in your body 
20101231194351.000|20101231194353.000|TR0|decreases.
20101231194353.000|20101231194356.000|TR0|
20101231194356.000|20101231194358.000|TR0|MYERS:  Can it detect my cancer stem 
20101231194358.000|20101231194400.000|TR0|cells?  I've heard a lot about this 
20101231194400.000|20101231194403.000|TR0|lately, cancer stem cells.
20101231194403.000|20101231194405.000|TR0|
20101231194405.000|20101231194407.000|TR0|LECHNER:  Right.  So cancer stem cells, 
20101231194407.000|20101231194410.000|TR0|people are doing some wonderful work on it 
20101231194410.000|20101231194412.000|TR0|and it seems to be sort of the key as how 
20101231194412.000|20101231194414.000|TR0|cancer spreads and starts.
20101231194414.000|20101231194417.000|TR0|
20101231194417.000|20101231194419.000|TR0|We're not actually looking at the cancer, 
20101231194419.000|20101231194421.000|TR0|which is what's so innovative about this 
20101231194421.000|20101231194424.000|TR0|approach.  Your body's immune system is 
20101231194424.000|20101231194426.000|TR0|altered any time the cancer continues to 
20101231194426.000|20101231194428.000|TR0|grow in the body.  So we're looking at a 
20101231194428.000|20101231194431.000|TR0|population of suppressive immune cells 
20101231194431.000|20101231194433.000|TR0|that get in the way of the body itself 
20101231194433.000|20101231194436.000|TR0|clearing the cancer.  This is the 
20101231194436.000|20101231194438.000|TR0|population we're detecting.
20101231194438.000|20101231194440.000|TR0|
20101231194440.000|20101231194443.000|TR0|MYERS:  How soon?  This year?
20101231194443.000|20101231194445.000|TR0|
20101231194445.000|20101231194447.000|TR0|LECHNER:  Yes, this year.  So at the 
20101231194447.000|20101231194450.000|TR0|University of Southern California we're 
20101231194450.000|20101231194452.000|TR0|going to be starting a pilot study in head 
20101231194452.000|20101231194454.000|TR0|and neck cancer patients in January and we 
20101231194454.000|20101231194457.000|TR0|hope to do melanoma and lung cancer next.
20101231194457.000|20101231194459.000|TR0|
20101231194459.000|20101231194501.000|TR0|MYERS:  Melissa, thank you so much.  I'm
